http://www.columbian.com/news/APStories/AP10252006news70357.cfm
 
 First, note this is a syndicated article.
 
 
Existing Home Sales Fall for 6th Month 
 Oct 25, 2:59 PM EDT
 By MARTIN CRUTSINGER 
 AP Economics Writer 
 
 
 WASHINGTON (AP) -- Sales of existing homes fell for a sixth straight month in September and the median sales price dropped on an annual basis by the largest amount on record, further documenting a lukewarm housing market.

 
 Lukewarm???? Largest YtY drop on record, and it "further documents a lukewarm market"?? 
 
 
The median price of a single-family home fell to $219,800 last month, a drop of 2.5 percent from the price in September 2005. That was the biggest year-over-year price decline in records going back nearly four decades.

 
 For those who are shopping right now, that is a 2.4% MtM decrease, on top of a 2.7% MtM decrease last month. Lukewarm indeed.
 
 David Lereah, the NAR shill, had this to say:
 
 
"The worst is behind us as far as a market correction - this is likely the trough for sales," said David Lereah, the Realtors' chief economist. "When consumers recognize that home sales are stabilizing, we'll see the buyers who've been on the sidelines get back into the market."

 
 It would be nice if he would actually put in some information as to what indicates to him that the worst is behind us. The last MtM decrease was the largest since the depression. This months decrease is the second largest since the depression. Where is the up side here??
 
 
The 2.5 percent drop in the price of single-family homes pushed them down to $219,800 while condominium prices fell by 3.2 percent to a median price which was also $219,800.

Wal-Mart is about as good a retail bellwether as it gets. 
 
 Let's not forget that consumer credit card and home equity loan interest rates are, one way or another, tied to the Fed rate. Both have become the the primary methods of financing purchases for the US holiday season by the general public.
 
 With declining housing values, increased credit burdens (from gasoline, stagnated wages and adjustable mortgages), increased debt service due to Fed rate hikes and an obviously declining economy, the only question I see is whether that dumb as a rock general public will max their credit out for the holiday season and retail takes the coming hit in 2007 or they tighten the belt now because they're already maxed out. Any guesses?

Everybody has an opinion about the housing market, so here's mine. This was buried in the 2005 annual enterprise report from OFHEO:
 
 "The growth in the volume of private-label (MBS) issuance has been unprecedented in recent years. And, unlike the volatility in issuance volume exhibited by the residential MBS market as a whole, the volume of private-label MBS issuance has increased consistently. Private-label issuance doubled between 2001 and 2003, and again between 2003 and 2005, rising to $1,191 billion last year, the highest volume ever. That was the first time issuance volume in the private-label market exceeded that in the agency market. The growth in the private-label sector in recent years has reflected the rising share of single-family originations comprised of nonconforming loans. More specifically, the increase in private-label issuance has coincided with the recent increases in lending to households not classified as prime and in originations of non-traditional loans. Private-label issuers not only purchase jumbo mortgages but also focus on the more credit sensitive mortgages, including adjustable-rate, subprime, and Alternative-A (Alt-A or reduced documentation) loans."
 
 I think this has been the fuel on the raging housing price fire. The housing market doesn't work unless investors are willing to hold the paper and the associated risk. Reasonable underwriting guidelines generally kept the market in check when traditional GSE issues were the predominant funding vehicle. But then Wall Street found a way to sell non-GSE pools to investors, and underwriting guidelines were drastically loosened.
 
 In 1999, Wall Street peddled IPOs for firms that had minimal revenues and no profits. The NASDAQ bubbled. In 2002, Wall Street began peddling private label MBS for homeowners who have minimal income and no chance of amortizing their mortgages. The housing market bubbled. In the end, the bankers will keep their profits, while the investors, owners, and taxpayers will suffer tremendous financial losses.
georged

 Agreed, nonconforming loans coupled with low interest rates for qualification purposes driving relaxed underwriting standards because there is a sucker market for the paper. Most private label issuers are totally vertical, packaging not only the loan paper, but also providing appraisals, insurance and escrow through subs, all for upfront points and fees. Pull up almost any Internet site and there will be a 'bad credit welcome' residential housing finance ad. 
 
 And investors gobble the paper up as soon as it's packaged.
xamnr

Does anybody know much about private label MBS? I know very little, and the information is terribly difficult to find.
 
 What types of credit enhancements are attached to these latest private label MBS?
 
 Who's buying the high-yield, first-loss tranches?
 
 I believe this is the root cause of the bubble. It's not so much that investment bankers are willing to sell the paper, because they've repeatedly proven they'll do anything for a dollar. But who is buying this stuff? The investors make the bubble possible.
 
 Jeff

 Both Fanny Mae and Freddy Mac have been through countless investigations, including restatements of income, massive fraud to promote commissions and every other dirty trick that puts normal business people in the pen. I know of no instance where any official from either quasi-government organization has received more than an offer to resign.
 
 As to who buys them; everyone associated with a pension fund, banks trade pools for 10-basis point gains (big money for paper transactions), investment firms handling 401k contributions use them as a hedge against equity market fluctuations and a good chunk were sold to foreign investors until the USD started taking a battering from US public debt and current administration policy. I personally don't know anyone who would touch them unless they were involved in a trade and quickly out the door. Attach the words bond, AAA rating insinuation, government and anything is easy to sell.

Credit default swaps also appear to be fuel on the housing price fire. Private label MBS and CDO issuers are thought to have reduced and controlled the risks in part by purchasing default protection. However risk cannot be reduced or controlled with default swaps, only shifted to others who are willing to accept the risk, or to others who don't fully realize the risks they've assumed and were not fairly compensated for the options they sold.
 
 Counterparty risk will be disastrous in 2007. When the counterparties fail to meet their obligations, the true flaw in default swaps will be painfully evident. Options effectively reduce and control risk when an exchange stands between the counterparties, but default swaps don't include a secondary repayment source.
 
 Who sold the default protection? Insurance companies, hedge funds, trading departments inside banks? Does anybody know?
 
 Jeff

 Never involved with real estate default swaps. My operational experience is dated, but at that time we used specialty insurance companies to absorb pension fund cash liquidations as annuities. Discounted basis for their up-front fees and many did fail after skimming the cream off the top. The feds always picked up the tab under the pension guarantee act. I'd think establishing entities for default insurance would be fairly simple to put in play as major insurers would write for them on a fee basis which included a fee commission to provide fee cash flow to the re-insurer. What's cap reserve to liability would be an interesting number. Big money in the real estate bubble with no federal safety net for investors. Just like the dot.com bubble?

 It is my understanding that in additional to specialty insurers, a lot of those loans are being underwritten by some 401K churners.
 
 Traditionally, home defaults occur at one of the lowest rates of any loan type. Many have applied this logic in the current market without taking into account the fact that applying the standard model to a non standard market is a recipe for disaster.
 
 I also know for a fact that a lot of those private labeled MBS's ( I would go out on a limb and say "most") are operating without a net. They count ont he fact that to most americans "bond" means "safe" and have no problem selling their junk. Additionally, based on historic rates (again, relying on standard data in a non standard market), the historic data for those types of bonds is very strong.
xamnr

This is borderline malpractice. Today's USA Today has a full page ad from NAR. It reads, in part:
 
 A message from the leadership of the National Association of REALTORS.
 
 It's a great time to buy or sell a home.
 
 Right now may actually be one of the best times to buy a home. Consider these facts:
 
 INTEREST RATES ARE NEAR RECORD LOWS
 
 LARGE INVENTORY WON'T LAST
 
 PRICES OVERALL HAVE STABILIZED
 
 POSITIVE OUTLOOK
 
 REAL ESTATE IS A GREAT INVESTMENT
 
 
 Each of the above headings is followed by a few facts supposedly supporting the statement. For instance, consider these gems:
 
 Contracts for home sales in August are up 4.3 percent and the outlook is for home prices to increase next year. 
 
 Alan Greenspan recently said "Most of the negatives in housing are probably behind us. The fourth quarter should be reasonably good, certainly better than the third quarter."
 
 The national median price of homes bought ten years ago has increased 88 percent.
 
 That last statement is a flat out misrepresentation intended to mislead the public into believing there is no housing bubble. According to OFHEO's housing price index, the median price increased about 90% from 1980 to 1996. From 1996 to 2006 the median house price increased 95%, but from 2001 to 2006 the median price increased 70%, whereas the median price increased just 25% from 1996 to 2001.
 
 The average annual appreciation over the life of the index was 6.6% through 2001, and the annual average from 2001 to 2006 has been 19.0%.
 
 NAR is obviously very concerned about the market, or they wouldn't be telling stories.
 
 And don't even get me started about Greenspan's blunders in all of this mess.
 
 Jeff
xamnr

There are infinite ways to slice historical data. This can shed some light on our current situation. All the following data is based on the median house price in the first quarter of each year, based on OFHEO's HPI.
 
 Year over year average median house price appreciation (all U.S. homes):
 1980 - 1990: 4.88%
 1990 - 2000: 3.31%
 2000 - 2006: 8.96%
 
 Recent growth has been two to three times greater than historical averages. That is shocking. Have you looked at a graph of median house prices? It is scary.
 
 California's real estate market bubbled in the late 1980's and early 1990's. That experience is worth revisiting.
 
 The average YoY growth in California's median house price was 4.83% from 1980 to 1986. The bubble began in 1987 when the annual YoY growth was 9.4%. The average YoY growth from 1986 through 1990 was 14.52%. Growth then fell to a YoY average of -1.6% from 1990 through 1997. The median price fell 13.4% from the high (3Q 1990) to the low (1Q 1995). It took over 8 years for the median house price to get back to the high of 3Q 1990.
 
 The average YoY growth in California's median house price was 8.12% from 1996 to 2002. The bubble began in 2003 when the annual YoY growth was 12.84%. The average YoY growth from 2002 through 2006 was 19.47%.
 
 The first bubble lasted about four years (1986 to 1990), during which the median price grew about 72%. This latest bubble has lasted 4 years (2002 to 2006), during which the median price grew about 97%.
 
 Granted, employment problems were the primary cause of the first California bust, whereas non-employment factors have caused this nationwide bubble and impending bust. But I'd argue this bubble and bust are far more serious for many reasons:
 
 * Economic malaise slowly caused the first California bubble to bust. Unwinding of speculation and bad monetary policy are rapidly causing this nationwide bubble to bust.
 
 * The recent bubble has generated far faster growth, and the total growth is significantly larger.
 
 * The first California bubble was not significantly fueled by speculators. Most home owners actually lived in their homes, owned only one home, had good jobs, and could afford to amortize their home loans. The current bubble has been largely driven by speculators, many of whom own two or more homes, don't have good jobs, and could never possibly amortize their home loans. California home owners did everything they could to keep their homes in the early 1990's. Many of today's home owners will give up and walk away soon because attempting to keep these homes would be economically stupid.
 
 * Walking away is going to flood the market with homes during the next 6 to 12 months. This is going to cause unprecedented downward pressure on home prices.
 
 * Finally, and most importantly, the California bubble was essentially a California problem. It didn't spread very far. Our current bubble is a nationwide problem. This is going to hurt everyone, including me, and it is going to be far more than a housing problem.
 
 By the way, I haven't introduce myself. I'm Jeff from Salt Lake City. I'm a bank examiner and CFA charterholder. I was a banker and broker before becoming a bank examiner. My wife is a manager with a regional home builder, so my predisposition to caution is reinforced daily when she tells me how 'things' are going at her company.
 
 Jeff
daewoo

 First, it is nice to meet you. It is always nice to see a new person on the board...especailly one who is rational and has a little experience in the financial world. Far too many peopel running around with no clue basing their financial arguments on blind faith.

 Check out his wikipedia page (thats right, his irresponsible cheerleading actually got him his own wikipedia page) at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Lereah

Daewoo, I would agree the California bubble began with the dot com insanity, and other areas experienced similar growth. Two notable areas are Denver and Austin, both of which began experiencing substantial increases in foreclosures and past due loans during 2004 and 2005. They are ahead of the curve.
 
 But the current bubble, based on OFHEO's index, began sometime after the terrorist attacks, and became a nationwide problem 2004: (YoY median house price growth):

 Many states throughout the rust belt and midwest have essentially been immune to this bubble, however the overall median price has soared. This underscores the risk in those markets that overheated:

 And while only 40% of all U.S. homes are located in the overheated markets, the homes represent more than 80% of the total value of all U.S. homes.
 
 Finally, NAR frequently runs ads on TV, radio, and in newspapers touting the extensive training provided to REALTORS, including in-depth training on ethics. It's one thing to be a sneaky scheister, quite another to be a sneaky scheister while publicly declaring your purity and goodwill. I've been collecting every quote from NAR during the past 12 months.  How can you say that? My government and other self-serving parties are telling me the economy including the housing bubble is fantastic with nothing but more greatness to come. I defer to daewoo's post about the Hindenburg.
xamnr

I don't think the government should be in the business of predicting the future, whether good or bad. Unfortunately politics trumps economics, so neither side misses an opportunity to use single bits of meaningless data to support its agenda. Democrats say the economy is terrible, while Republicans say the economy is healthy. When the democrats are back in control, the parties will swap strategies. The truth almost always lies somewhere in between.
 
 The real danger is the average American is sorely uninformed, so these little sound bites can have a significant impact on consumer psychology. And our economy is at the mercy of consumer sentiment.
 
 The housing market has looked dangerously unbalanced for more than 12 months, but only recently have the talking heads picked up the story. And only recently have home sales slowed and prices reversed their steep trajectory. This demonstrates the power of popular opinion in our economy. It is sad that most people need Katie Couric to let them know when its time to be concerned...
 
 Jeff
daewoo

Daewoo, I would agree the California bubble began with the dot com insanity, and other areas experienced similar growth. Two notable areas are Denver and Austin, both of which began experiencing substantial increases in foreclosures and past due loans during 2004 and 2005. They are ahead of the curve.
 
 But the current bubble, based on OFHEO's index, began sometime after the terrorist attacks, and became a nationwide problem 2004: (YoY median house price growth):

 
 I guess my thought is basically this. I think that we shoudl have seen a severe recession following the dot com burst, including stagnation, if not deflation, in home prices. A trillion dollar bubble burst is a major economic even in an economy the size of ours, especially the size it was at the time.
 
 Instead of seeing that major recession, including the hit to home values, we saw a relatively minor recession and home values started ot increase. This was because Greenspan convinced the fed that they had to crash interest rates in order to save the economy.
 
 Interestingly enough, that same year he told congress that they needed to take steps to encourage home ownership.
 
 Greenspan knew damn well what he was doing. He looked around following the dot com burst for a market that could absorb a trillion dollars. The only one big enough was real estate, so he went with that. He knew full well he was building a housing bubble. Instead of the major correction that we were due, we got a little bump and a few years of recession. 
 
 I will admit that my claim about when the housing bubble actually started is largely based on specualtion of what would have happened if the US economy had been allowed to take the hit it had coming as opposed to prolonging (and ultimatly intensifying) the inevitable. At the same time, the numbers do add up. Go back and take a look at the "end" of the dot com crash and the economic data for those years. Factor in a trillion dollar real loss to the economy. Use the most conservative numbers you can come up with, and even with the most conservative numbers imaginable, you are still looking at a severe recession, if not a mild depression. 
 
 
 
Many states throughout the rust belt and midwest have essentially been immune to this bubble, however the overall median price has soared. This underscores the risk in those markets that overheated:

 
 Immune to the building of the bubble. I doubt there is any such thing as immunity to the bursting. I woudl imagine that those "immune" states will be dragged down just like everywhere else. I know that in my state (KS), we largely avoided the bubble alltogether. Despite that, the RE market here has dwindled down to nothing and prices are falling. Part of that seems to be due to overall economic conditions, but there is also a pervasive bearish sentiment when it comes to the RE market, and much of that is based on the demise of the real estate bubble. I liken it to the dot com crash (again). Not just tech stocks went down the toilet, there were broad losses across the board.
 
 
Finally, NAR frequently runs ads on TV, radio, and in newspapers touting the extensive training provided to REALTORS, including in-depth training on ethics. It's one thing to be a sneaky scheister, quite another to be a sneaky scheister while publicly declaring your purity and goodwill. I've been collecting every quote from NAR during the past 12 months. It will be entertaining to revisit those quotes late next year. In fact, I think I'll post them on every forum I can find. :)

 
 It just floors me that there are Americans who actually listen to the NAR and take their word as gospel. We are talking about an industry group that unquestionably has a vested interest in seeing RE prices increase regardless of fundamentals. This is akin to writing a letter to the Ford motor company and asking them who makes the best vehicles.
georged

It just floors me that there are Americans who actually listen to the NAR and take their word as gospel. We are talking about an industry group that unquestionably has a vested interest in seeing RE prices increase regardless of fundamentals. This is akin to writing a letter to the Ford motor company and asking them who makes the best vehicles.

 
 There are people who unquestionably believe everything their government claims, so you shouldn't be surprised.
xamnr

The next wave of bad news is terribly timed. During the week of November 27, just as the holiday shopping season is gearing up, we will have three housing releases - new home sales, existing home sales, and the OFHEO third quarter HPI report. NAR has been fudging the new home sales data for two months, and it probably isn't possible to hide much more, so I'm betting the new home sales report is going to be ugly. Existing home sales data trickling in from state economic departments indicates the existing home sales decline will be even more gruesome than last month's data, if that is possible. But the HPI report will be the most painful since it is a quarterly report. Prices and sales have fallen a long, long way since June 30. I have a feeling many people won't be in a shopping mood after that.
 
 One thing will certainly happen when the dust settles. The government is going to roll out massive, restrictive, anti-competitive mortgage lending laws and regulations. Wall Street has proven it can't police itself, so the government will do it for them. I still believe the housing bubble has been largely driven my private label MBS growth. The housing market doesn't work without investors. Dumb people will always make dumb financial decisions, but a lack of willing lenders and investors normally prevents these people from doing much harm to themselves or others. But during the past 4 years Wall Street has opened the flood gates for subprime mortgages and non-amortizing loans, and they somehow convinced investors to buy the paper.
 
 Jeff
daewoo

 You forget...this is November, which means we will be looking at october numbers, which is where the serious winter "adjustments" set in.
daewoo

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20061114.whousingg1114/BNStory/Business/home
 
 
U.S. housing slump deepens, spreads
 
 Washington - First, Americans quit buying homes. Now, they may have stopped fixing and furnishing them too.
 
 Home Depot Inc. reported a 3-per-cent drop in profit in the three months that ended in October, amid mounting evidence that the U.S. housing slump is getting worse.
 
 "I don't think we've seen the bottom yet, and I don't see anything that says it's going to get significantly better in 2007," said Bob Nardelli, Home Depot's chairman and chief executive officer.
 
 Mr. Nardelli said job losses in the home construction market are the worst he's seen in 35 years, and the pain is starting to spread to the home renovation market.

 
 
 bob Nardelli is no cherry,a dn has never been an alarmist. If he is concerned enough to get up and speak this openly, I would say there is a serious problem out there.
georged

October housing numbers:
 
 New homes - down 14.6%, lowest since 7/2000
 
 Building permits - down 6%, lowest since 12/1997
 
 Any guesses on the NAR honey-coated press release?
Steeeeve

I don't see why people are so upset about the housing market crashing...oh wait, thats right, I was smart and didn't buy a McMansion. Yeah, if you got one of those I'd be peeing in my pants right now. 
 
 Let me know when you are selling your house for a third of what you paid for it and I'll buy it, tear it down, and build a real home.
daewoo

I don't see why people are so upset about the housing market crashing...oh wait, thats right, I was smart and didn't buy a McMansion. Yeah, if you got one of those I'd be peeing in my pants right now. 
 
 Let me know when you are selling your house for a third of what you paid for it and I'll buy it, tear it down, and build a real home.

 
 The problem with this is that a bursting housing bubble will be economically devestating to everybody, regardless of their housing situation. 
 
 Housing has carried the economy for the last several years (including this year). A drastic decrease in the housing market will almost certainly see us in recession. Factor in the loss of easy capital from refinancing of overvalued mcmansions, and the consumer spending that comes with it, and one has to wonder....recession or depression? 
 
 I am not kidding here. Figure housing (construction and associated activities) with its flowthrough multiplier between 4 and 6, depending on whose numbers you like. Figure refinances and that consumer spending with a reasonable flow through multiplier, and you are looking at serious, serious problems.
xamnr

Attention clueless journalists:
 
 Cyclical businesses must be analyzed on a year-over-year basis.
 
 Would you compare Wal-Mart's November sales to October's sales? No, becaue November sales will always be about 100% more than October sales. You must compare November 2006 sales to November 2005 sales due to cyclicality.
 
 Housing is also a cyclical business. The Wall Street Journal can't even get it right, much less the handsome talking heads on TV.
 
 Housing permits did not fall 6.3%. They fell 28.0% from one year ago.
 
 Housing starts did not fall 14.6%. They fell 27.4% from one year ago.
 
 Does anybody even bother reading the press release? Here it is:
 
 http://www.census.gov/indicator/www/newresconst.pdf
 
 No wonder the average American has no idea the housing market is about to seriously screw up their plans for the next 2 to 3 years.
 
 Edit:
 
 The Wall Street Journal, ABC News, CBS News, and NBC News all reported housing starts falling 14.6%. PBS was the only source I've seen yet to report the true 27.4% decline.
 
 Jeff
georged

Thanks for the link. I read media reports and don't recall annualized numbers, but upsetting advertiser markets isn't to their benefit.
 
 I've always felt this is just the beginning of an in the toilet trend for the housing industry. I commented in a post prior to your contributions that I thought it insane to consider any industry with a 25% loss of business with harder times ahead as viable. That's a pure service industry with few reserves. It'll be decimated including labor, material suppliers and financial support services. Associated bond failures are a different issue.
daewoo

 Cyclical businesses must be analyzed on a year-over-year basis.
 
 Would you compare Wal-Mart's November sales to October's sales? No, becaue November sales will always be about 100% more than October sales. You must compare November 2006 sales to November 2005 sales due to cyclicality.

 Jeff

 
 The clueless journalists know this. You sill notice that when the MtM numbers are happier, they report those. When the YtY number looks better, that is what gets reported.
Steeeeve

The problem with this is that a bursting housing bubble will be economically devestating to everybody, regardless of their housing situation. 
 well "devestating" to us means that we can no longer afford the 5 cars for a 3 person family and you can't travel to Hawaii twice a year....boo hoo.
 
 
Housing has carried the economy for the last several years (including this year). A drastic decrease in the housing market will almost certainly see us in recession. Factor in the loss of easy capital from refinancing of overvalued mcmansions, and the consumer spending that comes with it, and one has to wonder....recession or depression? 
 Meh, its the financing that the problem...ie debt...not really the fact that no one is buying the POS house.
 
 

 I am not kidding here. Figure housing (construction and associated activities) with its flowthrough multiplier between 4 and 6, depending on whose numbers you like. Figure refinances and that consumer spending with a reasonable flow through multiplier, and you are looking at serious, serious problems.
 It happens, I'm ok with it.
daewoo

well "devestating" to us means that we can no longer afford the 5 cars for a 3 person family and you can't travel to Hawaii twice a year....boo hoo.

 
 Your view of "devestating" is far too optimistic. From a purely practical standpoint, we may well be looking another "great depression" in the face.
Steeeeve

Your view of "devastating" is far too optimistic. From a purely practical standpoint, we may well be looking another "great depression" in the face.

 
 In all honestly, a humbling may not be a bad thing for this country. I doubt we will hit great depression levels but the people from the great depreciation certainly learned what to value in life.
daewoo

In all honestly, a humbling may not be a bad thing for this country. I doubt we will hit great depression levels but the people from the great depreciation certainly learned what to value in life.

 
 I woudl agree that a little humble pie may be a good thing for our economy as a whole. I have said before that neither a high economy nor a low one are as good as one that accuratly reflects underlying fundamentals. 
 
 The problem I see with the coming dose of "humbling" is that it is likely to be self perpetuating, with no real bottom in sight. Housing prices fall, which discourages purchasers (after all, why buy today when you can buy cheaper tomorrow), which lowers prices even more. Our equity markets (stocks) which are certain to take a SERIOUS hit as well suffer from the same thing. All the while, the dollar tanks, further devaluing everything in sight. 
 
 IMO, the deciding factor is going to be public reaction to a sharp decline in the standard of living. Crime during the depression era was rampant, and there were not folks wandering around back then hopped up on crystal meth and willing to kill for a pair of sneakers.
unlawflcombatnt

I think the most telling information comes from Federal Census Bureau information on total New Home completions vs. New Home Sales. The annualized rate of completions is roughly 1.9 million, the annualized sales are less than 1.1 million. I've made a copy of this, as well as having links to this information. Unfortunately I don't have enough posts at this time to include the links or the graphic here. 
 
 However, I'll come back and post them here when I do have enough posts. This information can be found at my homepage listed in my profile.
georged

That inventory would seem in line with the past six-months drop in annualized new home sales published monthly. We all know developers kept building due to investment money being in the pipeline even when sales started falling off. With transactions from existing sales also dead in the water, 2nd quarter economic numbers are going to be very interesting. I don't have a model, but wish I did just to see how close the GDP drop is to forecasts. The last two quarterly numbers have failed, even when vigorously massaged by the government and readjusted in following months, to perform anywhere near forecasts. 
 
 NRA statements will probably require a gallon or so of high-proof beverage for belief.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Putting a positive spin on housing crash
